conclusion: Two small balls of mass m each with charges +q and -q respectively, are connected by a rigid massless rod of length d, forming a dipole.
The dipole is parallel to the XY-plane and placed in a uniform magnetic field B perpendicular to this plane.
Initially, the dipole is aligned with the X-axis and has an initial angular velocity ω0 in the XY-plane.
Its center of mass is at the origin with an initial velocity v0 parallel to the XY-plane.
Given v0=0, find the minimal ω0=ωmin necessary for the dipole to reverse its orientation during the motion.
The image shows a dipole consisting of two balls with charges -q and +q connected by a rod of length d.
The dipole is aligned along the X-axis with angular velocity ω0 indicated.
The magnetic field B is shown as perpendicular to the XY-plane.
The dipole experiences a torque due to the magnetic field, which affects its angular motion.
To reverse its orientation, the dipole must rotate by 180 degrees.
The torque τ on the dipole is given by τ = p × B, where p is the dipole moment.
The dipole moment p is given by p = qd.
The torque τ = qdB causes angular acceleration α.
Using τ = Iα, where I is the moment of inertia, we find α = τ/I.
The moment of inertia I for the dipole is I = md^2.
Substituting I into α = τ/I gives α = qdB/md^2 = qB/m.
To reverse orientation, the dipole must achieve angular displacement θ = π.
Using θ = ω0t + 0.5αt^2, solve for ω0 when θ = π.
The minimal ω0 is found to be ωmin = 2qBd/m.
